data.value: IPL is a leading technology supplier to the resources and agricultural sectors committed to helping create a sustainable and decarbonised world.
Titanobel - Acquired by Dyno Nobel to leverage technology in new markets.
Majority stake in Australian Bio Fert Pty Ltd (ABF) by Incitec Pivot Fertilisers to develop sustainable fertilisers.
Easy Liquids (formerly Yara Nipro) - Acquisition enhancing storage and distribution network.
Create two market leading companies, each with a dedicated purpose, vision and leadership.
Accelerate growth through technology and customer solutions.
GHG emission reduction targets, net zero ambitions.
Subject to final Board approval, shareholder and other third-party approvals.

IPL's demerger proposal, with the intention to create two market leading companies in Dyno Nobel and Incitec Pivot Fertilisers, was announced. The demerger is subject to final Board approval, shareholder and other third-party approvals. Strategic review of Waggaman plant to be undertaken in light of positive outlook for global ammonia market and external interest in the plant.
Acquired 100% of the shares in Explinvest, the holding company of the Titanobel Group - a leading French industrial explosives manufacturer and drilling, blasting and technical services provider.

A Front End Engineering Design (FEED) study is underway for a Carbon Capture Facility at Waggaman capable of processing up to 950,000 metric tonnes of CO₂ to transport via a pipeline to a permanent geological sequestration site. Emissions from the plant represent 45 per cent of Dyno Nobel's total greenhouse gas emissions. If it proceeds, this project alone could reduce these emissions by approximately 30% against the 2020 baseline, or about 800,000 tonnes of CO₂ per year.
Acquired the Easy Liquids (formerly Yara Nipro) business to provide increased liquid fertiliser options and enhanced security of supply for farmers across the east coast of Australia.
Green ammonia production a step closer

Partnering with Fortescue Future Industries, IPL commenced a FEED study into the industrial-scale production of green ammonia at our Gibson Island fertiliser manufacturing facility. The proposal under investigation involves the construction of a new ~S5OOMW hydrogen electrolysis facility at the site to produce green hydrogen as well as the retrofitting of IPL's existing ammonia manufacturing facility to run on the green hydrogen produced onsite. Should the project proceed to a final investment decision, it would be Australia's first industrial scale green ammonia production facility.

Working closely with the Federal Government, IPL mobilised expert teams to work on expanding manufacturing capability and increase Australia's supply of AdBlue - an essential product to keep diesel vehicles moving.
Majority stake in Australian Bio Fertilisers
Acquired a majority stake in Australian Bio Ferts (ABF) which is seeking to develop a new category of sustainable fertilisers for Australian farmers.

Made the difficult decision to cease traditional fertiliser manufacturing at IPL's Brisbane-based Gibson Island plant after exhaustive efforts were unable to secure an affordable long-term gas supply. The potential conversion of Gibson Island manufacturing assets shows our commitment to pursuing.

data.value: We are committed to doing business ethically and in accordance with high standards of corporate governance.
The Board of Directors is responsible for charting the direction, policies, strategies and financial objectives of the Company.
The Board serves the interests of IPL and its shareholders, employees, customers and the community.
Responsible for day-to-day management and implementation of approved business plans.
The Board has established four standing Committees: Audit and Risk Management Committee, Nominations Committee, Remuneration Committee, Health, Safety, Environment and Community Committee.
The governance framework aligns the flow of information and accountability from employees to the Board.
Complied with ASX Corporate Governance Council’s Corporate Governance Principles and Recommendations (4th Edition) throughout the 2022 financial year.
Range of policies and practices set ethical standards for directors, employees, contractors, and third parties.
Global code for business conduct applying to all directors and employees.

Experienced executive and chemical engineer with roles in international refining, petrochemicals, oil, and gas; 30-year career with BP globally.

elements.title: Long Term Value Metrics Conditions and Goals

data.value: Our integrated platforms and facilities across high quality markets enable us to drive advantage in management of our supply chain and deliver competitive value to customers.
The stretch goal is Reliability of 95% by FY24 vs historical baseline average of 85%. This represents upper second quartile reliability by FY24.
If FY24 reliability performance exceeds the reliability measures, the relevant condition will have been satisfied.
Our explosives technology enables us to capture market share in a world which increasingly relies on innovative solutions to meet customer needs.
Delivery against a Board-determined Compound Annual Growth Rate (CAGR) schedule.
Our competitive position in our existing markets allows for strategic geographic expansion, facilitating diversification to different mining sectors and grow exposure to future facing minerals.
Board-determined EBITDA target that requires a capital internal rate of return (IRR) of 12%-15%.

elements.title: Sensitivity Analysis of Financial Parameters and Their Impact on Recoverable Amounts

data.value: This table presents a sensitivity analysis showing the impact of various parameters on recoverable amounts and impairment charges. The analysis covers both AUS and US currency measurements, with significant negative impacts shown across different scenarios. Notable impacts include a terminal value growth rate causing a (303.3) AUSmill change in recoverable amount and a (594.2) US$mill impact. The post-tax discount rates of 40.5% and +0.5% show substantial effects on recoverable amounts in both currencies.

This table presents sensitivity analysis for Fertilisers APAC, showing changes in recoverable amounts across different scenarios. The analysis includes various Australian dollar amounts (in millions) and Euro amounts. All values shown are negative, with the largest impact being AUD 653.0 million under the US$50 per tonne scenario. The European operations (Titanobel) show smaller impacts of EUR 9.4 million and EUR 14.3 million under different scenarios.

elements.title: Impairment of other property, plant and equipment

data.value: During the year ended 30 September 2022 other property, plant and equipment was impaired by $4.5m (2021: $3.2m) as a result of the Group’s fixed asset verification procedures. Additional impairment of $209.9m in relation to the Cheyenne and Gibson Island facilities was recognised as an Individually Material Item in the prior year.

elements.title: Responsibilities of the Directors and Auditor

data.value: The auditors report no material misstatement in the financial report.
Directors are responsible for preparing a true and fair financial report according to Australian Accounting Standards.

The risk of not detecting misstatement from fraud is higher than from error.

Auditors evaluate accounting policies and estimates made by the directors.
Auditors conclude on the appropriateness of using the going concern basis for accounting.
Auditors obtain sufficient appropriate audit evidence regarding financial information.
Future events may affect the Group's ability to continue as a going concern.

IPL operates in highly competitive markets with varying competitor dynamics and industry structures. The actions of established or potential competitors could have a negative impact on sales and market share and hence the Group’s financial performance.
Continuing global geopolitical uncertainty, supply chain disruptions, inflationary pressures and global recessionary risks may exacerbate risks.
IPL seeks to maintain competitive cost positions, invests in new technologies, monitors growth trends in the mining sector, and has a separation process in place for the demerger.
IPL supports the international climate agreement developed at the 2015 Paris Conference of Parties.

elements.title: Broad Risk Category Description and potential consequences

data.value: IPL’s operations are inherently dangerous due to exposure to operational risks such as unintended detonation of explosives and toxic releases.
IPL’s business is subject to various laws including anti-bribery, sanctions, and anti-trust laws which may impact business operations.
The challenge of attracting and retaining critical talent could disrupt operations.
Comprehensive HSEC management systems and strategies are in place to mitigate risks.
Potential legal and claims exposure during operations.

elements.title: Broad Risk Category Description and potential consequences

data.value: IPL’s manufacturing systems are vulnerable to equipment breakdowns, energy or water disruptions, natural disasters and severe weather events, unforeseen human error, sabotage, terrorism, and other unforeseen events which may disrupt IPL’s operations and materially affect its financial performance.
There is a risk that a reliable, committed source of natural gas at economically viable prices may not be available for IPL’s global manufacturing operations.
Sulphuric acid supply into Phosphate Hill would likely be negatively impacted from a volume and/or price perspective, should the Mt Isa Mines copper smelter close.
The loss of key customer(s) may have a negative impact on the Group’s financial performance.
Customers’ inability to pay their accounts when they fall due may expose the Group to customer credit risks.
Timely and economic supply of key raw materials represents a potential risk to the Group’s ability to manufacture and supply products.
Weaker hard and soft commodity prices could have an adverse impact on the Group’s customers and has the potential to impact customers’ demand, affecting volume and market prices.
The Group implements an Operations Risk Management Program, engages in business continuity planning, and maintains global industrial special risk insurance.

Foreign exchange movements against the Australian dollar may materially affect IPL's financial performance through the translation of US$, CAD$ or EUS denominated sales, borrowings and related interest payable.

IPL's capital management strategy is aimed at maintaining an investment grade credit profile, an appropriate mix of A$/US$ debt, funding flexibility by accessing different debt markets and reducing refinancing risk by ensuring a spread of debt maturities.
Cost and availability of funds, interest rate movements, and tariff changes
Financial risk management is undertaken in accordance with policies, including hedging strategies, approved by the Board.
Changes in tax legislation or compliance requirements in various jurisdictions
IPL engages with governments and stakeholders to understand and mitigate potential adverse impacts of proposed fiscal/tax changes.
Exposure to sabotage, terrorist attacks and other unforeseen events affecting operations and supply chain
Strict processes for stewardship and handling of dangerous goods; Business continuity planning and disaster preparedness across all sites.

elements.title: Sustainability and ESG Initiatives in IPL

data.value: IPL is focused on achieving Net Zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2050 or sooner.
The company aims to deliver sustainable growth while managing material issues.
In FY22, IPL acquired the Yara Nipro liquid fertiliser business and a majority stake in Australian Bio Fert Pty Ltd to enhance soil health.
The company adds value through manufacturing excellence, innovation, and sustainability beyond profitability.
The approach includes proactive management of long-term sustainability issues relevant to community welfare.
Vineyard photograph showing mature purple wine grapes on vines with green foliage, including some fallen grapes on the ground.
Business report image with overlaid text about economic community contributions.

elements.title: Zero Harm: Our Number One Company Value

data.value: Safety of people, customers, and community
Industry leading performance in occupational health, personal safety, process safety

data.key: Total Recordable Injury Frequency Rate (TRIFR) FY22

data.value: 73% decrease over the last three years
Physical and mental health and safety of employees
Established and stood down in March 2022
Implemented systems for health and safety protocols
83% of sites had zero recordable injuries in FY22
Quality investigation outcomes improved by sharing 92% of learning across the business
Monitoring system compliance actions completed on time
To deliver sustainable growth and shareholder returns while caring for our people, our communities, and our environment.
IPL is committed to operating in a manner which acknowledges and proactively manages issues material to the long-term sustainability of the business.
Conducted biennially following GRI guidelines, with the last assessment in 2021 to identify megatrends impacting value creation.
Scheduled for February 2023 prior to the Annual General Meeting.
Committed to sustainably delivering products to customers in mining, construction, and agriculture.

data.value: Approval of Moranbah Tertiary N2O Abatement, installation planned for 2024.
Short term absolute GHG reduction target of 5% by 2025.
Projects identified which support a >42% reduction pathway to 2030.
FEED study underway with a $13.7m ARENA grant secured.

Integration of Scope 3 GHG management into Business Unit strategies.
First comprehensive Modern Slavery supplier audit completed.
11% reduction in Australian municipal water use due to recycling efforts.
Investing $4.3m to expand Enhanced Efficiency Fertiliser product capacity.
Achieving 2022 target of zero significant environmental incidents.
Achieving ISO:14001 certification of Carthage manufacturing facility.
Formally committed to and participating in the UN Global Compact.

elements.title: Natural Resources Use and GHG Emissions

data.value: This table shows sustainability performance metrics across Economic, Environmental, and Social dimensions from 2017 to 2022. IPL's total performance has shown steady improvement from 68 in 2017 to 73 in 2022. Economic dimension shows the strongest performance, peaking at 81 in 2021. The company consistently outperforms the chemicals sector average, which has declined from 53 in 2017 to 26 in 2022. The data appears to be related to Dow Jones Sustainability Indices scoring.
IPL has been included in the Dow Jones Sustainability Index since 2010 and has been assessed according to the FTSE4Good criteria for the ninth consecutive year.
IPL has been a voluntary CDP (formerly Carbon Disclosure Project) Climate Change reporter since 2009 and a voluntary CDP Water Security reporter since its introduction in 2014.
IPL became a participant in the United Nations Global Compact in August 2022 and will report annually on its progress.
Reducing emissions while providing explosives and fertilizer products.
Innovative products help in reducing GHG and increasing yields.
